sols_html:
To begin with, recall that unitary matrices don’t change the norm of a vector, in particular \(\|Ux\| = \|x\|\) and \(\|V^*x\| = \|x\|\) for all vectors x. Using the definition of the matrix norm of A we find that

\[\begin{aligned} \|A\| &= \max_{\|x\| = 1} \|Ax\| \\ &= \max_{\|x\| = 1} \|U(\Sigma V^*x)\| \\ &= \max_{\|x\| = 1} \|\Sigma V^*x\| \\ &= \max_{\|y\| = 1} \|\Sigma y\| \\ &= \|\Sigma\|\end{aligned}\]

where \(\displaystyle y = V^* x\) satisfies \(\|y\| = \|V^* x\| = \|x\| = 1\). In other words, the matrices \(\displaystyle A\) and \(\Sigma\) have the same norm. The norm of the diagonal matrix \(\Sigma\) is simply the largest absolute value of the its diagonal entries. Therefore \(\displaystyle 2 = \|\Sigma\| = \|A\|\).

statement_html:
Suppose that A is a matrix with singular value decomposition \(A = U\Sigma V^*\) where

\[\begin{aligned} U &= \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\ 1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \\ \Sigma &= \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix} \\ V &= \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt 3 & 0 & 2/\sqrt 6 \\ 1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 6 \\ 1/\sqrt 3 & -1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 6 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

(c) What is the matrix norm \(\|A\|\)? Give a reason.
